title: Egg owner ‘lied about dognapping’
text:
Share on Twitter 
POLICE are scrambling for answers after discovering the man who reported his pug Egg had been stolen at knifepoint allegedly made the whole story up. 
But searches for the 14-month-old pug remain ongoing, as police appeal for anyone with fresh information to come forward. 
Police have charged a 29-year-old man after he allegedly made a false report of an armed robbery in Sydney Olympic Park. 
The man told police that three unknown men armed with knives approached him while he was walking his dog on Australia Avenue on 9 February. 
He claimed the unknown men demanded he hand over his wallet and backpack and also abducted his 14-month-old pug Egg. 
Police had made a public plea for any one with knowledge of alleged robbery to come forward. 
Investigations, however, revealed inconsistencies in the story and the 29-year-old was last night charged by officers from the Flemington Local Area Command for allegedly reporting a false armed robbery. Detectives who were investigating the original allegations.. Source: News Corp Australia 
He has been issued a future court attendance notice for false representation resulting in police investigation. 
A police spokesman said the whereabouts of “Egg” is still unknown. 
Anyone with information on the dog is urged to contact police via Crime Stoppers. 
The initial reports of Egg’s dognapping gripped pet lovers on social media, with Twitter users using the “FindEgg” hashtag. 
“That’s like stealing a wee baby, pugs are literally like little babies, they’re very loyal to their owner, I couldn’t even leave mine to go into a shop or she would cry. Poor pug will be so upset,” one woman wrote on Facebook. Detective Inspector Paul Arnold addresses the media following the reports of a robbery. Source: News Corp Australia 
At the time of Egg’s reported abduction, his owner told Police he was “too distraught” to face media. 
“Not only does he have the trauma of being the victim of quite a severe robbery ... but also the fact that his prized possession, being a pug, has been stolen,” Detective Inspector Paul Arnold said. 
“Any person who has a dog knows what it’s like to go without a pet which you’ve nurtured and cared for.”
